snippet: Under the health care law, insurers must issue refunds if less than 85 percent of premiums pay for care. But people on employer plans may have to wait for the cash, if they see it at all.
abstract: Millions of workers whose health insurance is covered by their employer are wondering if they will see any direct payments from $1.1 billion in premiums that have been returned to corporate policy holders under the Affordable Care Act; employers must follow certain rules in distributing the rebates, but many are still deciding how, when or even whether to share the cash with their employees.
lead_paragraph: Under the health care law, insurers must issue refunds if less than 85 percent of premiums pay for care. But people on employer plans may have to wait for the cash, if they see it at all.

headline.seo: Health Insurance Refunds May Stall in Employers’ Hands
headline.main: Health Insurer Refunds May Stall in Employers’ Hands
headline.print_headline: Delay in Insurance Refund May Lie With Employers

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
